title-group.article-title: Gujarat Elections: The Sub-Text of Modi’s ‘Hattrick’—High Tech Populism and the ‘Neo-middle Class’

abstract.p: This article, while it will pay attention to the opposition parties—the Congress and the GPP—intends, in its first part, to scrutinize the mainstays of Narendra Modi’s election campaign with special references to high tech populism, his banalization of Hindutva, his notion of Gujarati patriotism and his defence of what he calls the ‘neo-middle class’. The second part that deals with the electoral results and the citizens’ voting behaviour, will show that Modi’s constituency is a by-product of an increasingly polarized pattern of social change and economic growth, the BJP receiving stronger support from urban dwellers, whatever their caste, gender and level of education may be.

body.p: In December 2012 Narendra Modi joined a very selective club of non-Congress Chief Ministers: along with Jyoti Basu and, more recently, Navin Patnaik, he’s one of the few who have been re-elected twice. If we believe him, his success has to be attributed to his achievements—especially those in terms of development—whereas his detractors highlight more his authoritarian methods and his marketing techniques that the financial support of the corporate sector allows.

Certainly, the BJP is winning the Gujarat elections since 1995—a record—by default, for political and social reasons: the Congress does not offer a very convincing alternative in the state and the low caste as well as Dalit parties2—which have played the role of game changers in the Hindi belt since the 1990s—are conspicuous by their absence (Jaffrelot, 2012c). However, Narendra Modi’s last election campaign shows that he has also capitalized on a rather new and effective populist style and that he knows how to address issues that are causes for concern to the middle class, an expanding group that definitely is his constituency.

This article, while it will pay attention to the opposition parties—the Congress and the GPP—intends, in its first part, to scrutinize the mainstays of Modi’s election campaign in technical terms, with special references to high tech populism, as well as in thematic terms with special references to his banalization of Hindutva, his notion of Gujarati patriotism and his defence of what he calls the ‘neo-middle class’. The second part, that is dealing with the electoral results and the citizens’ voting behaviour, will indeed show that Modi’s constituency is a by-product of a very polarized pattern of economic growth, the BJP receiving an increasingly important support from urban dwellers, whatever their caste, gender and level of education may be.

sec.title: The Electoral Campaign: High Tech Populism Takes Over
sec.p: The BJP has inherited from the RSS a collective ethos that reflects the motto of the Sangh: organization first (Jaffrelot, 1999). This emphasis on the organization (the ‘sangathan spirit’) explains the resilience of the Sangh Parivar and the way it has contained factionalism, in contrast to the situation prevailing in the Shiv Sena (whose division was largely due to the personalization and patrimonialization orchestrated by Bal Thackeray). But Narendra Modi, in spite of his past records as an RSS pracharak, has turned his back on the team spirit and has personalized politics within the BJP as early as 2002 at the expense of the old organic relations between the party and the RSS.

sec.title: Modi vs the Sangh Parivar?
sec.p: In 2007 already, the Swayamasevaks had not been asked by Nagpur to canvass systematically in favour of Modi in Gujarat (Jaffrelot, 2009). Five years later, the gap between him and the RSS had widened. The Sangh parivar local leaders resent the way their movements have been sidelined by the Chief Minister. In ten years or so the number of Shakhas has diminished from 1,500 to one thousand and attendance is ‘down by an estimated 50 per cent’ (Umat, 2012a). In the early years of the last decade, the Akhil Bharatiya Vidyarthi Parishad (ABVP) had 94,000 members—it has retained half of them only. The Bharatiya Kisan Sangh (BKS)—which had 22.5 lakh members in 2003—is only 6 lakh large today. This trend is sometimes due to issue-based conflicts (for instance Modi has fought against the BKS after the organization mobilized farmers on the electricity issue—we’ll return to the problem that Modi has with the rural part of Gujarat). But it reflects also his will to emancipate himself from the BJP’s fellow-travellers (Pravin Togadia, the VHP leader was, for instance, totally marginalized).

Not a team player within his own Hindutva family, Modi has antagonized former colleagues like Sanjay Joshi, his main rival in the Sangh Parivar of Gujarat, whom he has had expelled from the BJP National Executive in 2012. His non-accommodative attitude is also one of the reasons why former Chief Minister Keshubhai Patel—Modi’s predecessor—started a new political party, the Gujarat Parivartan Party (GPP) with other dissidents in spite of his age (he was 84).

But the RSS is clearly facing a dilemma. On the one hand the Sangh which works collegially and insists on the merger of egos in the organization resents Modi’s style and on the other hand he’s one of their best winning cards. Therefore the doors were, and still are, apparently wide open for talks. On October 21, 2012 Modi argued his case in Nagpur for three hours to contain the influence of his detractors (Joshi, Togadia and Keshubhai Patel). We do not know what has been the outcome of these in-camera meetings, but in Gujarat, Modi could not fully rely on the support of the RSS volunteers who either abstained from taking part in the campaign or supported Keshubhai—they often did it as old colleagues of the veteran politician.3 Incidentally, Keshubhai Patel left the BJP precisely because of the ‘self-centred’ style of functioning of Modi. Talking to VHP members he said:
When he [Modi] took over the state BJP, I told him that this race is altogether different. It’s called a ‘relay race’, in which the baton is handed over from one participant to the other. Each one uses his strength and ultimately the team wins, not an individual. But since Modi took the baton in this relay race, he has never passed it on. He refuses to loosen his grasp over the party. (Ahmedabad Mirror, October 24, 2012)

sec.title: Modi’s Populism
sec.p: Narendra Modi is probably the only electorally successful BJP Chief Minister who canvasses without a large RSS support. As mentioned above, he had already been largely deprived of the RSS network in 2007. In fact, he had then voluntarily emancipated himself from the Sangh parivar. These push and pull factors—the RSS distancing and his own sense of independence—have had cumulative effects and resulted in the making of a new brand of populism: In 2012 again, he personalized his election campaign, so much so that the party was hardly mentioned and no other state leader was on stage. He projected himself as the embodiment of Gujarat and—like any populist—tried to establish a direct contact with each and every Gujarati.

sec.title: High Tech Image Building: From Yatra Politics to Holograms
sec.p: Like in 2007, Modi started his electoral campaign weeks—if not months—before the others by resorting to Yatra politics. By October 9, his Swami Vivekananda Yuva Vikas Yatra was over—he had held 135 rallies in this framework. But touring the state was physically demanding and time consuming. Modi, therefore turned again to what I called ‘high tech populism’ in 2007. During the previous state elections, he had resorted to internet and mobile phones networks;4 five years later he made one step further while initiating a TV channel, NaMo channel—that replaced the ‘Vande Mataram’ he had started in 2007—and a series of virtual meetings: Modi’s hologram appeared on stage in 3D simultaneously in different locations (26 on December 2, for instance) to deliver his speeches to massive audiences which were mesmerized (some of his supporters even wondered: ‘Is this real?’). A hyper image-conscious Modi was capitalizing on the exceptional power of images in the Indian (Hindu?) civilization. According to an estimate, Modi intended to hold 132 holographic shows during the election campaign in order to communicate directly with a larger number of citizens, at the cost of 150 crores of rupees, according to some estimate (Nair, 2012).

But Modi continued with more standard practices too—so much so that he addressed 125 rallies in the first 15 days of December, that is ten meetings a day (Dave, K., 2012b). Even more than in 2007, Modi saturated the public space as a marketing genius—well advised by an American, APCO Worldwide firm which had already worked for him during the previous election. At that time, APCO, which had already tried to refurbish the image of the Nigerian dictator, Sani Abacha, of the life-president of Kazakhstan, Nazarbaiev and of the former Russian oligarch, Mikhail Khodorkovsky, had reshaped the image of Modi for 25000 dollars a month (The Times of India, October 17, 2007).5 We do not know what the budget of the 2012 elections was but Modi has obviously spent more money than his rivals, probably thanks to the financial support of the corporate sector. The largest Indian companies have all invested in Gujarat more than before under Modi and their CEOs have been all praise for him during the recent meetings of ‘Vibrant Gujarat’, an annual function he had initiated.

sec.title: The Father-like Protector of Gujarat Against the Centre
sec.p: Modi used these channels of communication to project the same messages as in 2007. Among them his attempt at epitomizing Gujarat—and more especially the ‘Gujarati asmita’ (identity, soul)—against the Centre was a constant. He presented himself as the protector of Gujarat against the Union government. He claimed that he was ‘the chowkidaar’ of the Gujarat treasury, guarding it from the appetite of the Congress: ‘Earlier, this money used to get swallowed. Maaru koi Vhalu-dahalu nathi (I don’t have near and dear ones). The six crore Gujaratis are my family and their happiness is mine’ (The Indian Express, November 30, 2012b). His dedication to his task of chief ministership and the sacrifices it implied, is one of his favourite themes. In another electoral speech he’ll say: ‘I am a labourer who has not taken a break for an hour in the past 11 years in order to work for the development of Gujarat’ (The Indian Express, December 2, 2012d).

During his campaign, he concentrated his attacks in this vein against the Congress-led government in New Delhi—as if the congressmen of Gujarat were not worth targeting, as if there was no other Gujarati leader except him and as if New Delhi was his final destination. He arraigned the inaction of Manmohan Singh—whom he called ‘Maun (silent) Mohan Singh’(The Indian Express, October 30, 2012a). He accused him and Sonia of keeping mum about issues like inflation and poverty.

He tried to cash in on the anti-corruption movement launched by Anna Hazare against the federal government in order to project himself as ‘Mr Clean’. In his speech concluding his Yatra he said: ‘Friends, in the last eight years, have you heard any good news coming out of Delhi? All that you get to hear about is corruption, scams and favouritism (The Indian Express, October 9, 2012c). In the same speech he claimed that he has been victimized by the Centre ‘Of all the Chief Ministers that the country has seen in the last 60 years, I have suffered the maximum injustice at the hands of the centre’.

sec.title: The Banalization of Hindutva
sec.p: Another aspect of Modi’s campaign which pertained as much to his style as to his message has to do with the Hindu/Muslim relations. He highlighted his record regarding law and order and communal harmony and even connected both in the speech he made in Ahmedabad in conclusion of his first Yatra in the most paradoxical way. Arguing that in the past ‘Ahmedabad’s identity was curfew’, he claimed that he has been the one who re-established peace. He conveniently forgot that he was at the helm of the state government when occurred the most bloody post-independence wave of communal violence that Ahmedabad had experienced and asked the audience: ‘It has been 11 years … has the curfew gone or not? Have the riots disappeared or not? …. Today we have embraced the road of peace and brotherhood’ (The Indian Express, October 9, 2012). In order to project him as a friend of the Muslims too he launched another Yatra, the Sadbhavana Yatra. But in practice Modi’s election campaign was tainted with communal references—but not to the extent to the previous one, when he had tried to capitalize on the assassination of Sohrabuddin (Jaffrelot, 2009) (one of Gujarat’s ‘fake encounters’—see below).

In addition to Modi’s body language—and his propensity to wear saffron kurtas—his speeches were imbued with elements of the Hindutva rhetoric. Speaking before the Jain International Trade Organization (JITO), he accused the Centre for heavily subsidizing the opening of slaughter houses—a formula that was immediately translated as an attack against the cow in the media (Ahmedabad Mirror, October 29, 2012). One of his supporters, the BJP MP Navjot Singh Sidhu, went one step further by accusing Keshubhai Patel to eat gaumans (beef).6 The GPP leader retorted that the BJP was itself the ‘biggest killer of cows and the largest seller of gauchar’ (Dave, 2012c).

Modi, who received the support of another media savvy mass communicator, Swami Ramdev—who is closely related to the Sangh Parivar7—referred to the Hindu mythology during his meetings to counter Congressmen: ‘A Congress leader recently called me a monkey. Probably he hasn’t read the Ramayana or he would have known about the power of monkeys. I am Hanuman and six crores Gujarat is are my Ram whom I serve’ (The Times of India, November 19, 2012b). In a more communal vein, Modi attacked Ahmed Patel with some communal overtone after Sonia Gandhi’s right hand man, hailing from Gujarat, canvassed in his home state. He called him ‘Ahmedmian’ (Ahmed the Muslim) and tried to make people believe that the Congress had decided to project him as the party’s candidate for the post of Chief Minister: ‘Ahmedmian Patel says he does not want to be chief minister. But the Congress has already set the stage to make him the chief minister’ (Jha, 2012). Naturally, the Congress had no intention to project a Muslim leader in a state where, as Ganesh Devy says it is ‘natural’ to be anti-Muslim (Devy, 2006)—an assessment that may be exaggerated so far as the countryside is concerned.

In fact, the Congress nominated an unprecedented small number of Muslim candidates in 2012—and the BJP, none (again), in spite of Modi’s Sadbhavna Yatra. The Muslim president of the party’s minority wing in Gujarat resigned in protest. Last but not least, the only mention of the Muslims in the BJP’s manifesto—and the first one in an election manifesto of the Gujarat BJP under Modi—referred to the modernization of the madrassahs and to financial support to artisanal specialities (like making of kites, incenses sticks, rakhi and fire crackers), two items that reinforced the stereotype of the Muslim as a backward community—nothing was said about the spending of the scholarship received by Gandhinagar from the Centre for the minorities and that the state government refused to disburse.8

During the election campaign, the banalization of Hindutva in Gujarat was particularly evident from the fact that Amit Shah’s return to the state as Modi’s right hand man was hardly noticed. Amit Shah—a close associate of Modi, he was in charge of Home in his government till 2010—has been arrested, as a Minister of state, in 2010 because of his role in three allegedly fake encounters regarding Sohrabuddin Shaikh, his wife Kauserbi and their friend Tulsiram Prajapati. He spent three months in jail in Ahmedabad. On bail since then, he had not been allowed to return to Gujarat till November 2012. Then, he was re-elected in December last in one of Ahmedabad constituencies. But the Supreme Court has decided that his trial, along with those of a dozen of senior police officers who are implicated in several similar fake encounters cases, will take place in Mumbai because of pressures over the witnesses (Samervel, 2010). Interestingly, nobody—neither among the media, nor among Modi’s political opponents—made an issue of the company he keeps to contest his ‘Mr. Clean’ image, probably because any defence of the minorities is self-defeating in Gujarat politics.

sec.title: Development for Who?—The Making of the ‘neo-middle class’
sec.p:
The key word of Modi’s election campaign was ‘development’, like in 2007 when he projected himself as the ‘Vikas Purush’. But this time, he focussed more on the emerging urban middle class, a group that was called the ‘neo middle class’ in the BJP election manifesto which read:
Due to development in Gujarat in the last 10 years, there has been substantial rise in this neo-middle class. We want to address their issues. We will form a committee to define this neo-middle class. We will try to give them benefits of government schemes. (The Times of India, December 4, 2012e)

Generally speaking, the BJP manifesto was more oriented towards the urban dwellers than before. Among the relevant items one can cite the promise to construct 50 lakh houses, the increase of the age limit for entry into government jobs from 25 to 28, English medium schools, ₹ 2000 crores for flyover and underpass in cities, the building of mono rails and BRTs (Bus Rapid Transfer System of Ahmedabad, also known as Janmarg) in places other than Ahmedabad (where these projects are already on) and insurance schemes. These are typically promises aiming at wooing the urban middle class. To the peasantry, the BJP had much less concrete things to say this time: a nutrition mission would be set up, the minimum wages of labourers would rise (but to what extent?), tapped water supply would be extended to villages and—that was more precise—₹ 1000 crore Saurashtra Narmada Avtaran Irrigation (SAUNI) project would be implemented for filling up dams and water bodies of Saurashtra.

To focus more on his urban support-base made a lot of sense for Modi. First the re-delimitation of the constituencies had increased the number of urban seats, in a state where the proportion of rural dwellers was declining anyway. Second, Modi’s policy, over the last 10 years, has benefited urban middle class more than anybody else. Gujarat ranks only tenth out of 21 states in terms of Human Development Index because some groups of rural Gujarat continue to lag behind (India, Human Development Report 2011: Towards Social Inclusion, 2011, p. 24). Indeed, Gujarat is a case of social polarization with new rich in the cities and most of the groups which are at the receiving end concentrated in the villages. The number of families below the poverty line has jumped from 23.39 lakhs in 2000 to 30.49 lakhs in July 2012 according to the Rural Development Commissioner (The Times of India, November 19, 2012c). Unsurprisingly, 9 of the 11 lakh houses without electricity according to the Gujarat 2011 census are in rural areas. In terms of education, the excellent report of Pratham shows that rural Gujarat was lagging behind states like Haryana.9

Dalits and Adivasis (respectively 11.3 and 16.5 per cent of the state population) are even more specifically affected. For instance, the percentage of tribal underweight children (0 to 5 years old) is much higher in Gujarat than the tribal average at the national level (64.5 per cent compared to 54.5 per cent). The under five mortality rate of tribal children is also much higher. Similarly, the percentage of Dalit participation in the NREGA programme is three times less in Gujarat (7.83 per cent) than in India at large (22.67 per cent) (Outlook, December 10, 2012, p. 38). In fact, development has meant socio-economic polarization, because Gujarat is a typical case of growth without development for all. The Gujarat chapter of the India Human Development Report 2011 concluded ‘the high growth rate achieved by the state over the years has not percolated to the marginalized sections of society, particularly STs and SCs, to help improve their human development outcomes’ (p. 50).

sec.title: What Opponents?
sec.p: Opposition to Modi has been weak over the last ten years because of the inability of the Congress to put its house in order. First, there is an old contradiction between the discourse of the national leaders and that of the state leaders regarding the communal issue. In 2007, Sonia Gandhi had come to canvass in Gujarat and had lambasted Modi as a ‘merchant of death’ because of the 2002 pogrom, a formula that the Congress state leaders had found embarrassing because they feared it would alienate the Hindu voters. In 2012 national leaders came again with a similar discourse, but they diluted it. Sonia Gandhi, who was the first national Congress leader to visit Gujarat, addressed peasant issues and did not attack Modi frontally (Dave, H. 2012a, p.1). The Delhi MP Sandeep Dixit described Modi as ‘a blot on the nation’ and mentioned riots as well as fake encounters, but to the relief of the state leaders, he focussed more on the child mortality rate—saying that he would vote Modi the day this indicator improves significantly in Gujarat.

Second, the Congress of Gujarat has a problem of leadership. Not only the self-proclaimed ‘captain’ (The DNA, December 6, 2012a, p. 3) of the team, Shankar Sinh Vaghela comes from the RSS, but he’s locked in a competition with other—equally weak—state leaders like Arjun Modhwadia and Shaktisinh Gohil who, incidentally, lost their seats this time. None of these leaders have been projected as a contender for the post of CM because they all lack the needed charisma as well as authority and because that would have created an uproar from the other factions. Lastly, the Congress has been affected by badly managed ticket distribution that resulted in mini-riots at the party headquarters in Ahmedabad and in the defection of major Congress leaders who had been denied a ticket, like N. Amin (see below).

In fact, the main opponent to Modi has been the octogenarian GPP leader, Keshubhai Patel who dared to attack the Chief Minister like no other politician had done so far—which made the campaign more lively and persuaded the media to do their job less complacently this time. Giving an ever more pronounced communal overtone to the campaign, Keshubhai said that Modi was ‘like Mohammed Ghaznavi’ because he had 200 Hindu temples demolished in Gandhinagar in the name of city beautification (Ahmedabad Mirror October 24, 2012b, p. 8). He also compared Modi to General Dyer, the British officer who had been responsible for the massacre of Jallianwallah Bagh in 1919: ‘General Dyer killed 1,000 people, but Modi is responsible for the deaths of more than 39,000 people who have committed suicide due to unemployment and debt’ (The Times of India, November 19, 2012d). Last but not least, Keshubhai Patel also compared Modi and his clique to a ‘bunch of Dawoods’ (a reference to the mafia don Dawood Ibrahim) because of the ‘donations’ they extorted from the people (The DNA December 6, 2012b, p. 3).

Keshubhai Patel was that aggressive not only because he got the support of some Sangh parivar leaders as mentioned above, but also because he now represented something relevant in socio-economic terms: the rural sector that Modi had not treated as well as the cities, especially in Patel’s region, Saurashtra, where water had become an acute problem and where industry was lagging behind (The Times of India, November 6, 2012a). While the Narmada dam is providing drinking water to the cities, hundreds of villages have been ignored and, regarding irrigation, many of the minor and sub-minor canals which were supposed to be completed quickly according to Modi’s poll promises, are still to be built.

To sum up, the 2012 state elections in Gujarat did not only represent a contrast between Modi’s personalized style of high tech populism and a less effective and united Congress and a former BJP veteran relying on less modern techniques, but also between different socio-political agendas. While Modi’s BJP represented the urban middle (and ‘neo-middle’) class, the Congress was relying more on the rural poor and Keshubhai on the farmers. The newcomer—Keshubhai Patel—was clearly a cause of concern for Modi who, in sharp contrast with what he did in 2007, retained most of the outgoing MLAs in order to play it safe and tried hard (rather successfully) to woo GPP and Congress dissidents.10

sec.title: The Election’s Results: Erosion and Caste Diversification of the BJP-cum Social Polarization
The BJP’s Erosion: Was It Due to the GPP?
sec.p: The electoral performance of the BJP in Gujarat is declining slowly but steadily. In 2002 the party had reached an unprecedented vote share of 50 per cent in the context of the post-pogrom polarization.11 In 2007, the BJP lost one percentage point in spite of an aggressive campaign with some communal overtone. Five years later, it has further eroded in the same proportions.12 This is partly due to the slightly better performance of the Congress and its ally, the NCP (the latter won 1 per cent of the valid votes which may be added to the Congress’ 39 per cent), but probably also to the competition of the GPP.

sec.p: Clearly, the gain of the GPP in Saurashtra has partly been the loss of the BJP. But the GPP’s performance affected the Congress too, as is evident from the voting patterns of different castes, including the Patels. The fact that a peasant-oriented party, the GPP, made inroads in the Congress support base is consistent with the fact that both parties were more rural than the BJP.

sec.title: The Plebeianization of the BJP in Terms of Castes—not Beyond the OBCs
sec.p: In terms of caste groups, the BJP has diversified its electoral base in a very significant manner—up to a point. In Gujarat, caste identities are more fluid and fuzzy than in the Hindi belt, but social hierarchies along those lines continue to prevail. At the top of the status-related pyramid Brahmins represent 3 per cent and the Vaishyas (including Jains), 3 per cent. Rajputs (known as Darbars), 6.52 per cent according to the 2011 caste census,13 are less prestigious and more rustic—hence their alliance with some low caste groups to form the well-known caste federation called the ‘Kshatriyas’ in the 1950s–1960s.14 This alliance categorized as made of OBCs was intended to contain the rise of the Patels, a dominant caste which represents about 15 per cent of the state population, but which is divided into, at least, two sub-groups, the Leuva Patels (a ‘superior’ category concentrated in Saurashtra) that represents 8.11 per cent of the state population and the Kadva Patels (6.42 per cent) (Yagnik, 2012). Then come other OBCs, of whom the Kolis who were not part of the Kshatriya coalition represent 7.79 per cent.15 Another OBC caste is made of the Thakors (7.67 per cent). Other OBCs form 12.4 per cent of the state population.

While OBCs have the numbers, the Patels—who represent 21 to 46 per cent of the voters in 12 constituencies (Umat, 2012b, p. 1)—have become powerful because of their economic achievements and their sense of organization. The Leuva Patels are particularly well structured under the banner of the Khodhaldham Trust Samaj which organized a massive Maha Arti in the presence of Keshubhai Patel, in October 2012, to celebrate the first day of Navratri (Dave, H., 2012b, p. 2). Its president, Naresh Patel, was pressed to take side during the campaign but refrained from doing so (The DNA, December 6, 2012c, p. 1) and therefore the most frequently asked question during the campaign was: will the Leuva Patels support their veteran leader, Keshubhai or will they remain loyal to the BJP?

The BJP has traditionally been associated with the upper castes and the Patels. Under Modi, it has remained identified with the Patels (in 2007 33 per cent of the party MLAs were Patels—against 29 per cent in 1998) (Desai and Shah, 2009, p. 199). In 2012, the BJP nominated a large number of Patel candidates (see Table 3).

The BJP retained by and large the share of votes it had obtained in 2007 among the Patels, but the GPP’s gains on the Leuva Patel side (+ 32) have been the Congress’s loss (– 22) (see Table 4). After the elections, Kushabhai Patel claimed responsibility for having deprived the BJP from winning 15 seats more (Patel, 2012). But in fact, one may consider that the GPP, as a true opposition party, has taken away as many seats from the Congress since in 14 constituencies, its candidates’ number of votes is larger than the margin of the BJP’s successful MLAs. Among these seats, those where Leuva Patels have shifted in large numbers from the Congress to the GPP figure prominently.

Under Modi the BJP has plebeianized itself to a certain extent. The role of the upper caste declined (the proportion of upper caste MLAs decreased from 27 per cent in 1998 to 19 per cent in 2007) (Desai and Shah, 2009). The OBCs have been among the beneficiaries of this evolution. In 2012, Modi, himself an OBC, showed that he was aware of the fact that since the departure of Shankarsinh Vaghela, the BJP had no Kshatriya leader of the calibre of Congressmen like Vaghela, Shaktisinh Gohil or Bharatsinh Solanki. He decided to woo the OBCs, including the Kshatriyas, personally (Dave and Kateshiya, 2012, p. 4) and, more importantly, to give them a larger number of tickets (see Table 3).

sec.p: This move was one of the explanations of the voting patterns of the different caste groups. The proportion of upper caste and Patel voters supporting the party remains massive with, respectively, 60 and 61 per cent. But the BJP has lost 9 and 10 percentage points among these upper and dominant castes. Symmetrically, its main achievement comes from the inroads it has made in traditional vote banks of the Congress, the Kshatriyas and, even more, the Kolis. In the 1980s Madav Singh Solanki had solidly included these low caste groups into his KHAM coalition where ‘K’ stood for Kshatriyas, ‘H’ for Harijans (Scheduled Castes), ‘A’ for Adivasis (Scheduled Tribes) and ‘M’ for Muslims. The HAM’ groups are still supporting the Congress, and even more in 2012 than in 2007, but the OBCs are shifting towards the BJP. Among them the Kolis have on a large scale left the Congress (–16 percentage points) and rallied around the BJP (+ 12). As a result, Modi’s party is today almost as popular among the OBCs (54 to 56 per cent) as among the dominant and upper castes (60 to 61 per cent) (see Table 5).

sec.title: The Urban/Rural Divide and Class Polarization
sec.p: Castes and communities do not form homogenous entities any more in Gujarat because of class differentiation and the urbanization process. They need to be disaggregated according to criteria such as the urban/rural divide, a proxy for measuring class as well as the impact of the village vs. city cultures.

The Kolis are a case in point. While the Kolis living in villages are still supporting the Congress massively, those who stay in semi-urban and urban contexts have moved towards the BJP. More generally speaking, all the castes and communities (except the Patels) tend to be more Congress oriented when we consider their village dwellers.

Table 6 shows that the only constituencies in which the Congress prevails upon the BJP are the rural ones. And the more urban the voters are, the weaker the Congress is, as evident from its performances from 45.7 per cent of the valid votes in the rural seats to 32.2 per cent in the semi-urban ones and only 27.5 in towns and cities. The relation is equally linear on the BJP side, but in the reverse order from 43.3 to 50.8 and 57.7 per cent. This linear relation works in the case of all the OBC groups, including the Kolis in which case the gap between the rural and the semi urban voters is dramatic: 53.2 per cent of the rural Kolis voted for the Congress, but only 18.5 per cent of the semi-urban members of the caste. Symmetrically (almost), only 44 per cent of the rural Kolis voted for the BJP but 65.2 per cent of the semi-urban ones did the same. Similarly, the more urbanized the Adivasi voters are, the less Congress-oriented (47.3, 41.1 and 20 per cent) and the more BJP oriented (29.6, 35.6 and 66.7 per cent) they are. The relation is not that linear in the case of the Dalits and the Muslims, but the rural components of these two groups are still the most supportive of the Congress.

sec.p: The rural/urban variable seems to be more discriminatory than caste and community in several cases. The (partial) exception may be the Patels. In their case, the degree of urbanization hardly makes any difference. That can probably be explained by the fact that the Patels are both, urban and rural for a long time and form, therefore, a kind of straddling group. As early as the first half of the twentieth century, Patels have migrated to the cities for developing their business and joined colleges. Sardar Patel, an advocate, was elected mayor of Ahmedabad, while, as a child, he was working in the field with his father—an indication of the one-century old transition of the Patels to urban life. After independence, these agrarian capitalists who were so good at commercial agriculture invested in industrial ventures such as diamond cutting in Surat. They were clearly the main beneficiaries of the state policy supporting the small scale enterprises—and resisting the licence Raj (Sinha, 2005).
The discriminatory character of the urban/rural variable is reconfirmed from the way it prevailed upon two other parameters, gender and education (see Table 7).

caption.p: The Impact of Urbanization on the Voting Pattern of Genders
The Impact of Urbanization on the Voting Pattern According to Levels of Education

sec.p: While male and female villagers are more inclined to vote for the Congress than for the BJP, the more they get urbanized, the more they vote for Modi’s party. This trend is particularly marked in the case of women: village based women support the Congress more than male villagers, but urban women are more favourable to the BJP than urban males. The attraction for the BJP among urban women is truly remarkable, which suggests that in their case, the gender variable continues to play an important role along urbanization.17

Some linear correlations are again noticeable in Table 8. The more educated voters are the less likely ones to vote for Congress and more likely to vote for the BJP. This trend is strongly reinforced by urbanization. Rural voters who have not been educated beyond the primary level vote more for Congress than for the BJP, but the villagers who have got their matriculation and above will vote more for the BJP. However, the gap is the maximum among the educated urban citizens: only 19.4 per cent of the urban dwellers who had gone to college vote for Congress when 64.1 per cent of them will support the BJP. Education, and to a lesser extent urbanization and caste, are proxies for class. In 2012, the richer they were, the more likely the Gujarati voters were to support the BJP and the less likely they were to vote for the Congress—except for the poorest category which is the only one to contradict this linear relation.

To sum up, the typical BJP voter is not only, as it used to be the case, a man from the dominant/upper castes. Urbanization and education have made an impact on the social profile of the BJP electorate: a majority of the OBCs, mostly among those who have migrated to the cities, got some education and have become richer are now supporting the party, women as much as men, if not more. This change suggests that the BJP has diversified it, but to a limited extent only, since it has lost some of its supporters among the (mostly rural or semi urban) Dalits, Adivasis and Muslims. Indeed, the BJP—as is evident from its declining percentage of valid votes—has not broadened its base, but as diversified it in terms of caste. This is due to the polarization of society in terms of class that is reflected in the state’s voting pattern: in addition to the upper caste-dominated middle class, the mostly OBC-dominated ‘neo-middle class’ is now rallying around Modi while the rural voters, especially Dalits, Adivasis, Muslims and OBCs continue to extend their full support to the Congress.

sec.title: Conclusion: The Resistible Rise of Narendra Modi
sec.p: Narendra Modi’s third electoral success in Gujarat is in part different from his previous victories. Certainly, his style has remained the same: Modi simply keeps updating his brand of high tech populism based on his claim to embody Gujarat while protecting the state from the Centre, and he still relies on a discourse that combines Hindu nationalism (slightly de-emphasized) and ‘development’ (considerably over-emphasized). But it seems that he is now in tune with a constituency that goes beyond his traditional base (that is somewhat eroding) and comprises of an expanding urban ‘neo-middle class’ benefitting from years of economic growth. The rallying of a larger number of OBC voters belonging to this class suggests that the BJP is getting more plebeian in Gujarat in caste terms—up to a point. In fact, this diversification reflects a polarization in terms of caste and community since the party is losing out among the underprivileged groups, including Dalits, Adivasis and Muslims. Hence its erosion in terms of valid votes and the polarization of Gujarat politics since these groups are supporting the Congress in larger numbers, which explains the party’s (limited) electoral gains.

sec.p: However, Narendra Modi may benefit more than the Congress of the state’s socio-economic changes in the future. After all, Gujaratis are getting more and more urbanized and educated, and richer in the cities. In fact, Gujarat has registered the highest rate of urbanization over the last decade, jumping from 37 per cent of urban dwellers to 43 per cent between 2001 and 2011. The state may have a majority of its population living in towns and cities by 2030. Similarly, the literacy rate has increased from 69.14 per cent in 2001 to 79.31 per cent in 2011. These two variables, urbanization and education may seal the fate of the Congress if the party does not project a political alternative in the state, all the more so as, in contrast to other very urbanized states like Delhi (Jaffrelot, 2008), the Gujaratis living in towns and cities do vote a lot. During the December 2012 state elections, the turn out in urban constituencies was 68.1 per cent, not much less than the turn out of the semi urban (71.1 per cent) and urban (74.1 per cent) constituencies.

Already, the Congress has lost five elections in a row, the BJP’s successes in Gujarat being only matched by the CPI(M) in West Bengal—where, under Jyoti Basu the communists had established a form of domination that resulted also partly from their ability to identify with the state against the Centre, when the Congress was in office. Modi’s BJP is establishing a similar kind of hegemony. This notion, as Suhas Palshikar convincingly argues, is also due to the general political mindset. Indeed, ‘both the Congress and the general public in Gujarat operate within the ideological and policy paradigm set by the BJP. It is not just about electoral success; it is about a near-hegemony’ (Palshikar, 2012). Comparing the CPI(M) in West Bengal and the BJP in Gujarat, Palshikar highlights a major difference.

disp-quote.p: With all the aberrations the CPM was accused of, it never targeted any one section to construct its hegemony, nor was a personality cult perpetrated by it in West Bengal in spite of the towering image of Jyoti Basu. In contrast, the BJP is a majoritarian project in Gujarat and is also in bondage to Modi’s personal control. Modi’s distinction has been the ability to project a larger-than-life image of himself as personifying all the three elements listed above—thus, he becomes the expression of Gujarati asmita, Hindu nationalism and an untiring (his word in the victory speech) search for development’.(ibid.)

sec.p: While Jyoti Basu could never come to the Centre, one may wonder whether Narendra Modi could become more than a state politician. Certainly, Hindu nationalism and class polarization are more pronounced in Gujarat than in the rest of India, but he may attract supporters from the rest of the Indian (neo-) middle class by capitalizing on his clean image and the growth records of Gujarat at a time when the Congress party is facing a leadership crisis at the centre, is affected by corruption scams and seems unable to relaunch the economy and maintain law and order. The resistible rise of Narendra Modi may only be just beginning,18 provided he gets the support of his own ‘family’—which he may get by default19 and for financial reasons (Narendra Modi is probably the main fund raiser on the BJP side since the demise of Pramod Mahajan). Then Modi may have to convince his NDA partners, including Nitish Kumar—who did not even let him canvass in Bihar in favour of the JD (U)—that he’s a good choice for the 2014 elections.20

In the aftermath of the Sachar report, the Central Government has developed a pre matriculation scholarship scheme for Muslims: any Muslim student securing 50 per cent marks in annual exams, and with family annual income of less then 1 lakh ₹, was entitled to it. The amounts were between 800 and 1000 ₹ per year. Originally 55,000 students were selected . The Central contribution was about 3.75 crores. The State contribution was supposed to amount to about 1.25 crores. The Modi Government refused to implement it on grounds that it was discriminatory against other poor students. The matter went to the Gujarat High Court , wherein a division bench of three judges ruled in favour of the scheme. Later another division bench ruled against the scheme. Finally it went to a full bench of five judges. The noted Supreme Court advocate Dushyant Dave fought the case in favour of the Muslims free of charge. He won before the full bench, which directed the Government to implement the scheme immediately. In response, the Modi government turned to the Supreme Court, which has upheld the decision of the High Court in May 2013, five years after the scheme has been initiated. I am grateful to J.
